I think there may need to be another change made for pre-check
We do not want to short-circuit a subcloud that still has a kube upgrade object.
https://github.com/starlingx/distcloud/blob/master/distributedcloud/dcmanager/audit/kubernetes_audit.py#L144
I am just re-running some of the earlier tests to ensure the changes did not break anything
looks good so far

One additional design change to discuss is related to 'resume'

An enhancement might be to compare the version that is in-progress in the subcloud to the targetted to-version, and omit it if its already higher.
Currently if a subcloud has an existing kube upgrade in progress, it always gets resumed.

Scenario example: a person starts upgrading a subcloud to 1.20 and then realizes they dont want to do that yet.  So they upgrade all the other subclouds to 1.19.   There would not be a way to omit the one partially invoking its 1.20 upgrade,  without scoping by subcloud group, or un-managing the subcloud
The latest change fixes a 'resume' scenario in the subcloud where the oject returned by the API is not a dictionary
I think it would be reasonable to skip the resume if the target of the resume is higher than the specified to-version.

distributedcloud/dcmanager/common/utils..message: Something maybe unexpected is that "v1.22" will evaluate as less than "v1.22.0" since if you have two tuples that are mostly identical except one is shorter then the shorter one is considered to be "before" the longer one.
This is a bug.  I will fix in the next changeset
I'm wondering whether "from distutils.version import LooseVersion" could've been used as an alternative.

Maybe the first couple of versions of the utility, but with the requirement to make  v1.2 == v1.2.3  (ie: ignore extra fields)  it would not work using that mechanism

>>> from distutils.version import LooseVersion
>>> a = LooseVersion('v1.2.3')
>>> b = LooseVersion('v1.2')
>>> print(a < b)
False
>>> print(a == b)
False
>>> print(a > b)
True
>>>

This should be removed as precheck would have skipped the subcloud. This state is right after precheck state. I don't see how the target_version becomes None all of sudden.

if we were going to validate "to-version", maybe limit it to the versions listed in "self.get_sysinv_client(consts.DEFAULT_REGION_NAME).get_kube_versions()" ?

It's a bit unfortunate that kube_version_compare() will treat v1.21 as v1.21.0 rather than "whatever 1.21 version is available".
That is correct.  If we wanted to support that, I would need to alter the comparison check to stop based on the lesser of the two.  I can make that change if we want.

I am changing this in the latest changeset.
If you pass in v1.21  it will claim to be the same as v1.21.3 (or any v1.23.x)
which will likely mean fewer complaints from a customer, who knows they want 1.21 and dont really care about a micro version.

The problem with validating against the system controller versions is that it would then block the ability to pass in a sub-string ex: 'v1.21'

Another thing I wanted to future-proof for was to be able to explicitly patch a subcloud to something higher than the system controller (even though I know thats dangerous)  so a person could prototype patching and upversioning 1.22 in a subcloud before patching and/or upgrading the system controller to 1.22  (although this would add extra work related to the the image-pull step)
As it stands if you specify v1.21 as the target then I'm pretty sure it won't upgrade to 1.21.3 because that's a higher version than what was specified.
Remove as this file is added in 2021

Not sure how this is possible. The use case where an orchestrated kube upgrade is initiated while system controller is undergoing kube upgrade itself seems unrealistic. In any case, shouldn't this check be moved to the API so that kube-upgrade-strategy request is rejected if system controller active kube version cannot be obtained/determined.

I will re-setup my system controller to be in a partial upgrade state to verify the behaviour.  I only tested partial subclouds.  their output looks like
system kube-version-list
+----------+--------+-------------+
| version  | target | state       |
+----------+--------+-------------+
| v1.18.1  | False  | unavailable |
| v1.19.13 | False  | unavailable |
| v1.20.9  | False  | partial     |
| v1.21.3  | True   | partial     |
+----------+--------+-------------+

re-installed system controller and subcloud.
set kube versions so subcloud was out of sync.

Need to get to the control-plane step (first-master) to get system controller into partial state:

(use force if any alarms are present)
 system kube-upgrade-start v1.19.13 --force
 system kube-upgrade-download-images
 system kube-upgrade-networking
 system kube-host-upgrade controller-0 control-plane

 system kube-version-list
+----------+--------+-------------+
| version  | target | state       |
+----------+--------+-------------+
| v1.18.1  | False  | partial     |
| v1.19.13 | True   | partial     |
| v1.20.9  | False  | unavailable |
| v1.21.3  | False  | unavailable |
+----------+--------+-------------+

At this point, the code that determines the active version on the control plane will not find its value.
it also means audit will log the following:
 dcmanager.audit.kubernetes_audit [-] No active target version found in region one audit data
and set the endpoint out of sync as well
 kubernetes_sync_status      | out-of-sync     

The following will succeed:
dcmanager kube-upgrade-strategy create

the subcloud will be listed as a step:
 dcmanager strategy-step list
+-----------+-------+---------+---------+------------+-------------+
| cloud     | stage | state   | details | started_at | finished_at |
+-----------+-------+---------+---------+------------+-------------+
| subcloud1 |     1 | initial |         | None       | None        |
+-----------+-------+---------+---------+------------+-------------+

and when we apply it it hits this code:
dcmanager strategy-step list
+-----------+-------+--------+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------+----------------------------+----------------------------+
| cloud     | stage | state  | details                                                                     | started_at                 | finished_at                |
+-----------+-------+--------+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------+----------------------------+----------------------------+
| subcloud1 |     1 | failed | kube upgrade pre check: System Controller has no active target kube version | 2021-12-11 06:33:33.312066 | 2021-12-11 06:33:37.218177 |
+-----------+-------+--------+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------+----------------------------+----------------------------+

The alternative solution (for pre-check) would be to choose the 'target' partial kube version, since that is the most likely version to 'eventually' be active in the system controller.

Also note that the user can still orchestrate in this scenario if they explicitly pass "--to-version v1.21" (or something)  since then it wont try to determine a version from the system controller.
if "target_version" is 1.20.9 and "to_version" is 1.20, won't this end up setting should_skip to True?
Once I fix the util method, that scenario will return 0, so it wont skip.

puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/ma.message:
Puppet uses the resource title to ensure execs are unique.
https://puppet.com/docs/puppet/7/types/exec.html

You have 'update_controller-manager_conf'  defined at line 924.
However, the exec is identical, so even if this resolves to running that exec, the code will work.  Also, we have other places where we duplicate the exec title.

What I am not sure about (moving forward)  is what will happen if in the future, we change one of those 'update_controller-manager_conf' execs and not the other, since I am not 100% sure if puppet can scope by class or class loading order.

We have other execs in this file where we are doing the same thing.  So this is not a new concern, but one we should be aware of.

As you pointed out, this parameter is responsible for `Type: Alarm` data model defined in SOL003 v3.3.1, and data type is `Identifier`. `auto_increment` will automatically generate unique id for each alarm, but I don't think this is a good solution, because there's no need for using auto increment values for those identifiers.

Some additional details here (with your contributions from offline discussion): the "SomeObject.save_changes()" method is usually called when the object itself gets own fields/columns updated by "SomeController.patch()" call to "SysinvObject.save()". For example, "PtpParameter.save_changes()" is called in the line "ptp_parameter.save()" of "PtpParameterController.patch()".
Since the "patch()" methods of PtpInstanceController and PtpInterfaceController don't change ("save()") the object itself, instead they create new entries in the bridge table (ptp_parameter_ownerships), those "save_changes" methods for PtpInstance and PtpInterface objects can be removed.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/api/controll.message:
The trailing -  for these paths is not a convention I am familiar with.
I think this is fine.

This is for appending another value to the tail of an array field (usually a zero-based index would be used to point a specific position at the array), please see https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6902#appendix-A.16.
You may notice there is no such array field in host table, but instead this approach is being used to allow a list of instances to be assigned to the host (i.e. setting the corresponding ptp_instance_maps - the bridge table - entries). Same was done for PTP parameters assigned to PTP instances and PTP interfaces.

when the commit message contains too long lines, gerrit doesn't know how to render that and the whole look of the review is weird,
please check the commit message format: https://docs.openstack.org/contributors/common/git.html#commit-messages

Every commit message should have a title - first line, then an empty line should follow, then body of the commit message should follow.
Every line should be < 72 chars and in case you reference a bug, it should be referenced by a footer of the commit message:
Closes-Bug: #number
or
Related-Bug: #number and etc, see https://docs.opendev.org/opendev/infra-manual/latest/developers.html#development-workflow
Done

please keep the commit message formatted the following way:
<title of the commit message>
<empty line>
<body of the commit message>

ack, how can I set 'shared' value to True using neutron cli?
Any command or doc link, please?

As an SG owner, you can create an RBAC policy to share the SG for another tenant X. Then login to horizon as tenant X, you should see the SG with shared=true. https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/latest/admin/config-rbac.html#sharing-a-security-group-with-specific-projects

Assuming you're using devstack for testing. First, you need to install the latest Neutron to get the neutron-server side change: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/811242. Then you can cherry-pick this patch to your local horizon repo and set COMPRESS_OFFLINE = False in the local_settings.py so the code change can be effective. And after restarting apache2, you should be able to see the shared field and shared SGs in the horizon UI.

question (and confirmation inclding me): We need to check the neutron behavior when the API is called with admin role. What SG are returned? All "shared" SGs from all projects, or "shared" SGs shared to a target project? If the answer is former, it breaks the expectation in horizon (because the returned list is used when launching an instance).

IIUC perhaps it is the most tricky point when supportng "shared" somthing. From the same reason, horizon does not provide a good support for RBAC networks in case of admin role.

As compromise, we can support RBAC resources only for non-admin users and allow some heavy operations for admin users, but ....

Perhaps "all_projects=True/False" discussion in neutron might be needed to revive for a perfect support (but it will take time).

Good question. I have tested and confirmed the API behavior is the second case that given an admin role, it returns SGs shared to the target project too instead of all the shared SGs for any project. I have also added notes to the inline comment.

For more details, the shared field of networks/SGs is determined strictly by checking if the requester's project id is in the target projects of the object rbac entries: https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/b78771bbd58d34ff5a4872a666ce25110b5f2bb6/neutron/objects/rbac_db.py#L54-L63 And it works the same for admin and non-admin tenants.

* Not supporting DM multipathing fallback (I'm probably not fully understanding the NVMe implications)
* How the code will behave with enforce multipathing

I think these two points are closely related, lets make the decision there.

And thank you for the insights regarding volume identification details, specifically differences between existing os-brick implementation with iSCSI vs NVMe specs.

native->DM fallback - The way I see it now, based on volume id info, this would be possible in a situation where there is an (unintended) mismatch between all three: NGUID, EUI64, and Namespace ID. In that case, if all else is well (other hardware ID info is matching), DM may just take over automagically - maybe - and at which point the DM devices would need to be identified correctly. I think we haven't yet tested any of this os-brick NVMe multipath interaction with DM, so lets see if there aren't any complications even with the basic functionality.

enforce_multipath - If we decide to support native->DM fallback, enfore_multipath=True should first attempt this fallback, and fail the attachment if unsuccessful. enforce_multipath=False should also attempt fallback to DM, and if unsuccessful, fallback to singlepath.
If we leave native->DM fallback out for now, enforce_multipath=True will simply fail (instead of fallback to single path) when multipath connection fails.

So the decision is simply, support native->DM fallback or not?

I vote to leave it out from this implementation, due to differences in volume identification details, I think unexpected things can get ugly. I think there is a lot of real hardware testing needed to make a confident decision on doing it. And if left out, it can always be added later. 😊
If we do go with native->DM fallback, I think it would be better to leave the opinions to the users/operators, so rather than assuming this native->fallback, it should be configurable in another parameter.

Your DM multipath spec assumes that DM will multipath across two devices with different UUIDs.

Maybe we should note that if they are different then os-brick will have to use the device mapper to do multipathing.

The important thing with multipathing using iSCSI and FCP protocols is that both are running SCSI commands underneath, and the SCSI protocol defines the "Device Identification VPD page (83h)" which must remain the same through the life of a volume.  And I'm sure that's what Pure storage is using to present the 2 different physical disks as one when doing replication.

Our code in os-brick sometimes queries this information with the "/lib/udev/scsi_id --page=0x83 --whitelisted --device /dev/XYZ" and other times uses the value in sysfs that the udev connect rules stored.

I assumed that the NVMe protocol had something similar to uniquely identify a volume regardless of where or how it is being presented.

Looking at various places [1][2][3] I see that this is supported by linux and exposed in sysfs under /dev/nvmeX/wwid, but that it depends on the presence of different data (was probably added in different NVMe spec versions). 

From highest to lowest preference, it seems to be [2]:
- The NGUID
- The EUI64
- A concatenation of VID, Serial Number, Model and the Namespace ID

So, shouldn't we be able to support falling back to the DM option if the host does not support native multipathing?

[1]: https://www.nvmexpress.org/wp-content/uploads/NVM-Express-SCSI-Translation-Reference-1_1-Gold.pdf

[3]: https://lore.kernel.org/lkml/20170712133856.17211-1-jthumshirn@suse.de/

Two points about this:

1. I don't think DM should be used as a fallback for nvmeof native multipath. I now think that the only fallback that should be allowed is dropping from multipathing to singlepathing rather than switching between mechanism.

2. For DM - the storage backend is also responsible for assigning hardware id info for DM to recognize the seemingly two "physical" devices really being one - and therefore coupling them into one linux device. This is practically the same requirement as for native multipath except there it is NQN and namespace id - so, if nqn and namespace id are already messed up by the backend for (intended) multipathing to work, I doubt we should expect the DM-related backend requirements to be upheld (especially when unintended).

Essetially, the way I see it now, operators should be clear on the multipath mechanism they intend on using. Moreover, there needs to be a clear compatibility between the backend's capabilities and the intended mechanism. (As is what I mean in both cases where mentioning "the backend's responsibility")

And also, I now think that the only fallback that should be allowed is dropping from multipathing to singlepathing rather than switching between mechanism.

We may have a problem here, because the enforce multipathing check is something that currently happens on the host when it calls the "get_connector_properties" before calling cinder to get the connection information.

Changing it to be a driver responsibility would be a change in our code pattern and it may not solve all possible issues.

As far as I see it we have a couple of problems with using the enforce multipathing parameter, because Nova has a single parameter for this configuration that will be used for all os-brick calls, so we'll have problems if:

- We only have NVMe volumes and we want to only do native multipathing:  "get_connector_properties" will fail if enforce multipathing is True and multipathd is not running, even if we don't want to use it.

- We change the NVMe connector code to fail on the "get_connector_properties" if enforce multipathing is set to True and the host doesn't support native multipathing.  Doing this could break deployments that currently don't use NVMe devices and don't have native multipathing enabled/supported.

Right, I see the point now, I was misunderstanding enforce_multipath.

My thinking was among the lines of: if driver wants to do native multipathing (knowing host does support it) - but for some reason host fails to execute it, "enforce=True" would mean fail operation (or switch to DM) - rather than fallback to singlepath.

But now I'm understanding the point of enforce_multipath is different than what I imagined, it is not enforcement based on host failure to execute intended multipathed connection, but based on its capabilities (a check if multipathd is running)

- POST /tags (the multiple post) is documented to return a 409 ... under what conditions does this happen?  I'm asking because we have that weird PUT /v2/metadefs/namespaces/{namespace_name}/tags/{tag_name} call that iirc allows you to change the name of the tag in the database (in other words, PUT /tags/{name} with new-name in the request body is not equivalent to DELETE /tags/{name} followed by POST /tags/{new-name}).

What I'm getting at is that the Metadefs Tags API already has some weird behavior that needs to be explained clearly before you start changing it.  We need to distinguish clearly the situations under which tags are completely replaced vs. simply renamed or we may get some really strange regressions.

Hi Brian,
* The current behavior of a POST to tags/{tag-name} when a tag name already exist is that it returns a 409 response.
* POST /tags (the multiple post) returns 409 response when two tags with same name are present  request . For example we pass Tag1,Tag2,Tag1 it will return  a 409 response .
You should say that this is an optional header that takes a boolean value; if not present, the behavior is the same as passing "X-Openstack-Append: False".
Done
You also need to say what the new behavior is when the append payload contains an already existing tag.  Will it be ignored or re-created (see my question about PUT for an individual tag above)?

For the new behavior of POST /tags (the multiple post) if tag name already exists it will return a 409 response ,and no new tag will be created.
(If we pass Tag4,Tag5,Tag6 and Tag4 already exists the new behavior will return a 409 response.)

I'd like to hear why you don't want to use PATCH for this.  I think it would be better to use the appropriate verb rather than modify POST behavior with a header.

Another alternative is to use a query string to the POST call, for example, "?append=true" so that the behavior is explicitly requested as part of the URI instead of hidden in a header somewhere.

A third alternative is to do nothing in the API and make a client change that gives you a single command to accomplish something that takes multiple API calls.

* The reason we are not using PATCH is because we are adding(creating) new tags, PATCH is better in a case when we have large number of values to be provided to update a record, but that replaces not creates. So it doesn't seem to be a valid option

* The reason we are not using query string is, we are not using query parameters other than GET call so to be consistent with behavior in PTG we decided to use header instead of query parameter.

*  Handling it in client does not serve the purpose here as deployments which are not using python-glanceclient will not be affected with this change.

PATCH + json-patch allows you to remove, replace, or add; see
https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/glance-specs/specs/api/v2/http-patch-image-api-v2.html
You need to make clear that it is an optional header.
Done

No, it won't.  It will simply include the header along with whatever the user has specified (unless you are proposing to do some client-side processing, which I don't think you are).

Also, why do you need a boolean value for this?  Do you want 3 different behaviors:
1. no --append ... do not pass the X-Openstack-Append header at all
2. --append=false ... pass "X-Openstack-Append: false" (not really needed, but OK)
3. --append=true ... pass "X-Openstack-Append: true"

If you don't need #2, then you don't need this command line option to take a value.  If you do want #1 and #2 to be different, I would like to hear a bit more about why.
Ack

I disagree.  I think you want to allow an operator to make this call for troubleshooting purposes (for example, something isn't working, and you need to verify that the correct backend info is being passed in the JSON response in the correct format).  (The idea of the service role isn't to exclude operators, it's to allow inter-service calls that don't require full admin access on the part of the requesting service.)

Done

Instead of doing this by query parameter, I suggest adding a 'detail' resource so that the call is GET /v2/info/stores/detail ... then you don't have to worry about the default value of the parameter, etc., and it isolates the policy to a particular API call (instead of it applying partially to a different API call), and should make the code cleaner (were you planning to disallow non-admin users from using '?detail=' at all? Or would they be allowed to use '?detail=false' but not '?detail=true'? -- if get rid of the query parameter, you don't need to worry about these cases).

Yes, but a few things to think about:

1. Much as it pains me to say so, the Block Storage API is not a paragon of good API design.

2. The get-pools call isn't a good analogy here because the call itself (before you add on the query parameter) is already admin-only, whereas GET /v2/info/stores is supposed to be accessible to end users.

3. If you look at the cinder Backups API (next section in the api-ref from the link you give above), it follows the GET /backups and GET /backups/detail strategy (as do volumes and snapshots), so this is a common pattern in openstack APIs for getting the details.

4. Glance doesn't have GET /images and GET /images/detail, but that's only because the GET /images includes all the detail already.

5. The glance POST /images/{id}/actions/deactivate and POST /images/{id}/actions/reactivate follow this paradigm of using a URL resource instead of query parameter, so I think there's some precedence for this in the Images API v2.

So from an API design point of view, I really prefer the resource (instead of query parameter) strategy.

Why on the cinder side?  Why not add it to glance, and if new_config_opt=False, you either return a 204 with an empty response, or return the info/stores response without the new fields.  Since the multihash values are a glance concern, it seems like the glance operator should decide this.

When we start exposing cinder's volume type, or filestore's data dir path, does that check still makes sense for those cases since we are not doing any optimization with those properties.

Well, the glance check could happen at the API layer when processing the GET /v2/info/stores/detail call.  Cinder has to be able to handle getting a 404 (when it's a new cinder and older glance) for this call anyway, so if glance returns a 204, cinder will know that it should not do the optimization.

As far as the current unchecked optimization goes, I think that can actually be turned off on the glance side by not exposing the image locations.

I'd prefer to try to keep this on the glance side as much as possible.

Since the operation is initiated and executed on the cinder side, glance is just called to get the stores info and register the location of image so there doesn't seem to be a good place to add this config option check. Similar is the case when we use cinder store and apply the optimization of cloning the volume and the config option resides on cinder side. Also the glance team agreed in PTG to add it to the cinder side. Although i understand your point glance operator deciding it to be performed but there doesn't seem to be a good way to check this on glance side.

Another security impact is that currently, if you want to take advantage of nova-glance or cinder-glance optimizations, you need to expose the direct_url or image locations in the image-detail response.  Is there a way we can leverage this proposal so that we can finally put OSSN-0085 to rest?  See also https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/glance/queens.html#known-issues

You're correct, this is at the wrong granularity to address OSSN-0085.  But what I'm thinking is that if glance adds GET /v2/images/{id}/locations to the API, that call could be restricted to the admin or service user, and then the locations would not have to be exposed in the regular image-detail response.  But that's clearly beyond the scope of this spec.
That seems like a good idea and better way of handling the security vulnerability but as you mentioned, it is outside the scope of this spec.

I'm not exactly sure how this API will be able to handle that case since locations are image specific and this is related to store but maybe we can expose the generic location of a store which will require some good refactoring on cinder side (also we need to maintain backward compatibility) and obviously on glance side and it will make the proposed solution more complex than it already is (requires changes and coordination in 2 projects i.e. glance and cinder). I will mention the security impact here. The suggestion to enhance this API for dealing with OSSN-0085 is a good topic for discussion.

For the client, it might make sense to go with your original proposal of simply adding the --detail option to the current 'glance stores-info' call.  That way you can document the option like

  --detail   With sufficient permissions, display additional information about
             the stores.
Done

Also, since the abstract class is being used to define the interface, I don't think we want to allow arbitrary args and kwargs there.  So I'm OK with this change.

Hi Jessica,
 so this change protects the access to that array object, which is good, but
I think the underlying issue for this bug is not that array.

I think what we believe is happening is
- list of steps is queried from the DB  (all indicate the step is 'running')
- walk the steps and skip over and do nothing for most of them (they call into that method that has a debug log that indicates that a thread already existed.
- However while the steps are being walked, one of the threads completed, updated its DB and removed itself from the array.

So each place the array gets updated is likely to not compete for the lock.
It might make sense to have the array update not be permissible within the thread.  I am not sure.

It seems like the key change here is to adjust the subcloud workers list to be a 'tuple' containing the state of what it was when it was initiated.

Also note:  patch orch uses its own thread.  I would not suggest changing that.  
We will get these changes for free when we convert patch orch to a state system.

In the future we might consider some threadpool and callback registration.
also testing in https://review.opendev.org/q/topic:%22tempest-train-last%22+(status:open%20OR%20status:merged)
lgtm

Can we abandon this patch?

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> I don't know whether any of this needs to be addressed before approval into OpenStack, but I've noticed a number of divergences from OpenStack norms within skyline-apiserver which will make integration with our community goals, standard CI jobs, and release automation challenging for them:
> 
>   * Reimplements lots of common things from scratch rather than relying on Oslo (only minor use of oslo.policy currently)
>   * Organized as a "monorepo" containing half a dozen Python packages (when splitting, be sure to use Git's filter-branch tool in order to preserve existing commit history)
>   * Uses Git's submodule feature rather than loose cross-project interdependencies
>   * Package versions are hard-coded into files instead of deriving from Git metadata/tags
>   * Tox configuration is a naive wrapper around make
>   * Dependencies and test dependencies are not tracked in requirements files
>   * No global upper-constraints.txt integration for constraining dependencies to versions used by the rest of OpenStack
> 
> Note that these concerns are based on only a cursory skimming of the current repository, so there are likely a lot of other similarly nonconforming aspects I haven't spotted. I recommend the maintainers of this project review the templates from openstack/cookiecutter, as well as look at how the packaging and test boilerplate is done in established repositories like openstack/nova and openstack/oslo.config.

These are unanswered questions on packaging and release side, which I think we should know the answer/plan before approving the project for making them consistent with other OpenStack projects. Also few more additional questions:

* As discussed in PTG, what is the plan for projects plugins? does skyline provide plugin framework for other OpenStack projects like Manila, Magnum etc or how they can implement their UI in skyline.

Few of the things can be done/improved after this official project application is merged but we should know the plan and especially on packaging, release or other projects plugins plan side?

As discussed in TC PTG[1], we are ok to proceed with Skyline as official project but the python package/repos things needs to be set up in OpenStack consistent way.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-October/025554.html

A new discussion on the mailing-list would indeed be great to further increase visibility to the project.

Note that Skyline was discussed with Horizon team at last PTG:
https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/xena-ptg-horizon-planning#L141
The conclusion then was that the effort should be driven separately from Horizon, which will focus on maintaining the current solution.

As a result, Skyline is holding its own team gathering next week (Tue, Wed and Thu at 5UTC).
I think Skyline is ready to be accepted. While the repos require a little restructuring to fit with our release tooling, that shouldn't stop them from being accepted at this point.

Thanks for proposing the new project, please do the below two things as the first step:

1. Start an ML on openstack-discuss to have an initial discussion about the project
2. plan to discuss with Horizon team also in their PTG, this is their etherpad to collect the topic to discuss - https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/horizon-yoga-ptg

reference/projects.yaml.message:
as you mentioned in the PTG summary email, (http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-October/025541.html) 

-----------------
 skyline-apiserver has divided the source code into six sections:
  - skyline-apiserver: core source code of skyline apiserver
  - skyline-config: config library with yaml to parse config file
  - skyline-console: git submodule of skyline-console
  - skyline-log: log library with loguru
  - skyline-nginx: generate the nginx.conf file with openstack environment
  - skyline-policy-manager: generate policy yaml file

-----------------

As Fungi asked in the same ML, do you consider creating them as separate repo or just single repo which has challenge for packaging and release.

> Thanks, Zhu, for the updates and response. I am OK on the repo separation plan after merging this patch that is not blocking.
> 
> How about a UI plan for other projects like Manila etc. (like Horizon does with plugin framework)? is that also something you consider and have in your roadmap? If yes, then I am OK to gradually design/implement those; otherwise, if there is no plan for other project UI, we should think from the users' point of view on how they can use a unified OpenStack UI for their cloud(deploying different services).

Yes. For those other projects like Manila etc, we have plans to add those like horizon does with plugin framework.
- refactor some codes to support plugin ways
- give one demo plugin
- more detailed docs for how to add other projects dashboard

So that, the skyline-ui will only include the core projects like keystone, nova, cinder, neutron, glance. Ohter projects will be extended as a plug-in.

Thanks, Zhu, for the updates and response. I am OK on the repo separation plan after merging this patch that is not blocking.

How about a UI plan for other projects like Manila etc. (like Horizon does with plugin framework)? is that also something you consider and have in your roadmap? If yes, then I am OK to gradually design/implement those; otherwise, if there is no plan for other project UI, we should think from the users' point of view on how they can use a unified OpenStack UI for their cloud(deploying different services).

> as you mentioned in the PTG summary email, (http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-October/025541.html) 
> 
> -----------------
>  skyline-apiserver has divided the source code into six sections:
>   - skyline-apiserver: core source code of skyline apiserver
>   - skyline-config: config library with yaml to parse config file
>   - skyline-console: git submodule of skyline-console
>   - skyline-log: log library with loguru
>   - skyline-nginx: generate the nginx.conf file with openstack environment
>   - skyline-policy-manager: generate policy yaml file
> 
> -----------------
> 
> As Fungi asked in the same ML, do you consider creating them as separate repo or just single repo which has challenge for packaging and release.

In view of the several questions raised, we will gradually improve. For example, get rid of submodules, try to use more openstack common component libraries and so on.

However, I don't think these questions metionsed above should prevent Skyline from becoming an official openstack project.

Because we could make Skyline an officail openstack project at the same time while improving the skyline code specification. After entering the openstack project, it is more convenient for us to use the existing Zuul tools of openstack. And easier integrated with kolla and kolla-ansible.

Done

The idea is to keep the volume in reserved state during the re-image operation so end users couldn't perform data path operations on that volume during reimaging.
This is basically used as an intermediate state.
Shouldn't we wait until os-reimage has at least returned 202 or something before we do this?

That might lead to unexpected cases because after the re-image, cinder will update the empty attachment with connection information and might cause a race with this delete and updating the new attachment.
Also we are already checking (on L#46-48) if cinder microversion is new enough, to perform this operation, as a precondition which was the main concern of failure during PTG discussion.
Done
Why does Cinder need the compute host connector information here?

This was an optimization discussed during PTG, rather than nova calling cinder to first create empty attachment (attachment-create) and after getting the re-image complete event, calling cinder again to update attachment (attachment-update), we can directly pass the connector info in the reimage call and cinder will update attachment after the re-image is complete avoiding the back and forth dance between cinder and nova.
Done
You've dropped the need to complete the attachment from this section, that's still required to mark the volume as `in-use`.
Done

Ack, will update the current wording.
My thought was that the existing wording stated that and i didn't want to make much changes to the existing approved spec.
This will already happen when the instance spawns, there shouldn't be anything new to do here.
Done
Ack, will remove it.
nit - Need a space before this.
Done

What about multiattach volumes? Should n-api reject requests early or wait until c-api rejects them later?

Additionally this UX isn't great for users IMHO as they would automatically reimage their volumes when these requirements are met. I can definitely see a user accidentally doing this if they are using the `2.latest` microversion so IMHO it would be nice to add a request param to avoid that. Something like reimage_volume=True?

My issue is really with the introduction of a change in behaviour that destroys user data that's only toggled on by a new microversion. It's super super easy for end users to miss this if they are using 2.latest (they might not even be aware which microversion they are using in some envs tbh) and suddenly end up reimaging their volumes IMHO.

The attachment management will be trickier for multiattach volumes and the benefit will not be worth the effort. I think it's better if n-api rejects it directly so we don't go into an async call to c-api that will again require an external event from cinder and a user message notifying user of the failure which seems extra work. I will add a point about it.

I thought the idea behind implementing this is to not differentiate between rebuilding an ephemeral or volume backed instance and both should work same without much interference from user. If it's intended to be treated as a different operation, we can add the reimage_volume flag and a command line optional argument in novaclient to pass it for volume backed instances.
I will wait for confirmation before upating this part.

I tend to agree with Lee. Nova did not destroy the user data on the volume before but now it will. We need to be extra cautious as it is really destructive now but it wasn't before. So users has existing assumptions about it. 

Another option would be to infer the destructive intention from the delete_on_terminate flag on the BDM. But overall I think a new flag on the API would be a lot more explicit and safe.
Done
Continuing on with this discussion, is this due to the reimage API not allowing in-use volumes to be reimaged? If so it would be good to reference that requirement here.
Ack

Also considering the case of multiattached volumes, while reimaging, a volume could be in in-use state and some instance can have an ongoing IO operation on it which might have unexpected results. Since we are avoiding the case of multiattached volumes, the reserved state makes the most sense here to keep this operation safe.

The idea is to keep the volume in reserved state as the reserved state seems suitable for management operations on the volume and hence it will be implemented on the cinder side in the same way. The in-use state usually signifies that the volume is ready to use so doesn't make sense to execute this operation on it. I will add a point here.

Again continuing here, I don't like this even if it is trying to optimise the flow.

How does the updated connection_info get back to n-cpu? Through the external event payload?

I'd rather reuse existing logic in the rebuild flow and nova.virt.block_device etc to have n-cpu update the volume attachment etc rather than yet another unicorn codepath.
Done

Yes, the current idea is to return connection_info as event payload.
That's a good point if the nova team wants to keep consistency between operations and call the attachment_update itself rather than cinder doing that update. I will wait for feedback before updating this part.
FWIW this needs to happen with the changes to the rebuild API and new microversion etc. You might want to reorder things so that API change is done after the compute changes etc.
I think this point isn't telling much as we already have a documentation impact section, will remove it.
ACK sure, just making the point that this will need to land in tree in the same change that introduces the new microversion, param etc.
IMHO this change should have a Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder-specs/+/809622 as we can't commit to anything in Nova until the actual API design is agreed to in Cinder.
Done

We tend to cover both positive and negative paths in unit and functional, the latter just allows us to make actual API calls and assert behaviour without a full deployment.

(Yes our functional tests aren't real functional tests, essentially a greybox tests).
Ack
As above, I'd like to guard against accidents by including a request param to ensure users are opting into this behaviour. That should allow us to document this clearly in the API ref and elsewhere.
Done
Ack, just need confirmation that my understanding makes sense on L#46 and will update that part.
As above this really depends on the cinder spec and I'd like to see a link to the committed rendered Cinder spec referenced throughout this Nova spec before we commit.
Ack

Apologies I've been out sick for a few days. Returning to this hill that I appear to be dying alone on I'm still against passing the connector here. FWIW you would also need to pass the volume attachment UUID for this to work, something that is missing from the cinder spec.

IMHO it's easier and more maintainable for both parties if the os-reimage API just reimages the volume and fires off the external event to Nova. Nova can then update the attachment and continue with the rebuild as normal.
Done

supernit - Shouldn't the example here actually enable a reimage of the boot volume?
Done
What is the need for this parameter?  As a user I don't think this should be relevant.  If I want to reimage a boot volume I most likely wouldn't care if it's ephemeral or volume-backed, right?
Thank you for the clarification.  I think adding your explaining paragraph would be beneficial here.

https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/?expanded=rebuild-server-rebuild-action-detail#rebuild-server-rebuild-action

The previous behaviour of the API would retain the contents of the boot volume. Without this new parameter a user could request a rebuild with the newly introduced microversion (or more likely the 2.latest alias) and suddenly see their boot volume reimaged.  With this new parameter they now need to opt into the new behaviour by passing True *and* the new microversion.
nit: If
?: Will this reject volumes that support multi-attach, or volumes that are currently attached to more than 1 instance?  We should be explicit here.
Sounds reasonable, since users using read-only multiattach boot volumes is an unlikely scenario and the check is easier this way.

I believe this check will be on the multiattach attribute of the volume, so multiattach capable without checking for actual attachments. As we are talking about boot volumes I'm not sure this matters either way.

I think we should be clear about nova's expectations on this operation on the cinder spec and mention it here.

Does Nova expect the WWID of the volume to be preserved or not?  If cinder just attaches and copies data then the WWID will be preserved, but it may also change, since Cinder may decide to  clone the volume from cache or glance image.

I don't know if these WWID that are present at the host level are propagated inside the VM, but if they are then there could be cases where this change can be problematic.  Software that locks a license on a server fingerprint that includes disks' IDs.

Should we add an option in the ``os-reimage`` operation to tell cinder that creating a new physical disk is not an option?

The cinder volume ID will be preserved regardless of how cinder does the operation.
Yes the flow is clear, and if the volume's ID doesn't propagate into the guest then we are safe and it's irrelevant how Cinder performs the operation.

The WWIDs are not guest visable, the volume UUID is so we'd expect that to stay the same.

Nova should disconnect the original volume either way at the start of the rebuild before calling os-reimage and then reconnect with the fresh connection_info below.
Not necessarily. If cinder has the new image in its cache and just clones it then it will be faster.
Oh, I see, thanks.
I think the point here is that's slower than the previous behaviour of not re-imaging the volume.

This must have been a new policy that was introduced after wallaby was released?

Correct, and it's similar to the way that a few wallaby policies were split into more granular policies. In this instance, this ^^ new policy was added to govern access to a feature that in wallaby is governed by the "volume_extension:volume_type_access" policy. In Xena there are two distinct policies, whereas in wallaby they "share" a common policy.

What I am trying to say is, that if logrotate is configurable and user is able to change default cron_logrotate_rotation_interval: "weekly" via globals for example to hourly, cron's has to run minimal once per hour - this is not possible in current situation - because it's by default daily for logrote cron file.
ping
recheck

Ok, let's assume that you have very big load to servers, servers are logging tons of logs to your disk and your disk is limited.

For this purpose you have logrotate which is configurable via kolla-ansible, you can set cron_logrotate_rotation_interval and cron_logrotate_rotation_count. What does it mean ? It means when logrotate process will start, it will check logrotate's configuration, let's assume you want to logrotate logs every hour and want to store N count of logs.

So, you setup cron_logrotate_rotation_interval: 1 and cron_logrotate_rotation_count.

Problem is that logrotate process is executed via cron, and that cron is running *daily* on each distro.

So even if you want to run logrotate hourly (because you want to avoid situation when you will be out of space), you really need to logrotate often than one day - one day would be not enough as you can run out of space.

In current situation if you have for example logrotate weekly, and cron is running logrotate daily, everything is OK, because every day logrotate will be happy, because it is not already a week and on 7th day will logrotate files.

If you want to logrotate hourly .. it's not enough to run logrotate daily.

Is it clear ?

It was just example, you can configure logrotate to not follow a "time" but follow size of file. And if you are afraid situation with out of space, you really want to be less nervous than more - so you will do it every hour, not every day.

If you have debug on, it can be several gigabytes per hour * every service * 24 hours.

We are not discussing my setup, we are discussing feature in kolla which is usefull and not breaking anything, so where is a problem ?
Yes it is. But I still think that if you need logrotate being run hourly, there's something really wrong with your setup.

Manila just respects project_ids and not names, but thats not really end user friendly - i was thinking we can loop through the projects in the data that comes back, and resolve the names with the help of keystone, and then create a new column with project name before displaying the result.

Discussing about this a bit with gtema, we shared some interesting thoughts

1. Performance will be hurt by adding the project obj search
2. Other implementations on the openstack client are limited to return what the API returns. There are some especial cases (e.g. server info is extended with flavor details). No other service is extending project id with project name as we are intending to do.
3. The user might not really have priviliges to list/find project. This is unlikely, but could happen.

WDYT?

Hi Victoria, 

Thanks! Yes, all good points to consider:

> 1. Performance will be hurt by adding the project obj search

Yes, it'll slow things down for sure. keystone for example has a "--names" option to list names of projects (and users, domains) instead of IDs in commands such as https://docs.openstack.org/python-openstackclient/latest/cli/command-objects/role-assignment.html

The problem with displaying IDs is that its not as user-friendly in the CLI. We always accept project names as input in all the "openstack share" commands and we convert it into IDs before sending the request to manila - so this is in theory not slower than that. 

> 2. Other implementations on the openstack client are limited to return what the API returns. There are some especial cases (e.g. server info is extended with flavor details). No other service is extending project id with project name as we are intending to do.

I see; perhaps an improvement that we can suggest everywhere if we figure out what needs to be done 😊. I like the idea that you wanted to optimize this and add a helper within osc_lib. 


> 3. The user might not really have priviliges to list/find project. This is unlikely, but could happen.
By default we expect cloud users with the system admin role to be able to interact with group types (and share types). Users that access this command should also have access to the projects API from Keystone.


That said, i don't mind us creating an RFE for this and getting this patch in without project names.

designate/common/policies/base.py.message: Since we managed to delay this so far, this would have to be YOGA now?

Yeah, master is yoga, but some scoped tokens/personas patches previously merged and are broken, so I think we need to backport this.
This chain:
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/designate/+/763878

This was implicitly deprecated in Wallaby with the previously patches, just not clearly called out for the "default" path. It was a bug in those previous patches. That said, this isn't a big deal to me, so I will move it to yoga.
This all has to be backported to wallaby though, as those older patches are all really broken. How will we handle backporting this if it says "yoga" though it's the wallaby branch?

We don't have an option to not backport the deprecation. It's not just a statement for a countdown clock to remove the old code, it's used to decide which policy applies when the operator sets the "enforce_new_defaults" oslo_policy setting.
If we don't backport this, the rest of the API will switch to the new scoped tokens rules, but this one rule will not enforce scope. It was a big bug in the patches that were merged in Wallaby.
Hmm, I think then the best way would be to split the bugfix and the deprecation into two patches and only backport the bugfix. But maybe I am missing something here.
Hmm, I think we can backport the new policies, but not set the deprecation timestamp being in the past.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: I agree with Alex. Cleanup work such as removing deprecated code/features is generally a good idea in master, but the goal of stable releases is to avoid risks that could introduce a regression. I don't see the gain in reaching all the way back to the train release for something like this.

The auth_uri parameter doesn't exist in stable/train in most of the modules and I'm not aware of any risks caused by this. I we need this to avoid conflict when backporting https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/822306 later.

setting auth_uri after www_authenticate_uri is like dead code and confusing. We've  defaults which are used for services like glance[1] and it overrides what we set with auth_uri.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/puppet-glance/blob/stable/train/manifests/api/authtoken.pp#L195

As per code cleanup in stable branches, we backport stuff to drop cli command deprecation, so this is nothing in comparison.

Thanks for the explanation.  I did not read lines 54-73 closely enough.

I might not be very familiar with the original idea but my interpretation is there are 2 different ways this API could be invoked.
1) via cinder: when the volume is in 'available' or 'error' state
2) via nova: when the volume is in 'reserved' state

So 2 different policies governing different cases.

Regarding the 'reserved' state, from nova's perspective, a normal user should be able to rebuild their instance and we're using the same personas here as done in nova i.e. PROJECT_MEMBER_OR_SYSTEM_ADMIN[1]. It's dangerous as it's wipes out all the data but that's the purpose of this operation and i think the user should be able to understand it before initiating the operation. On our part, we are going to document this.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/policies/servers.py#L392
For the example, please use a JSON boolean type, not a string.  (Our request schemas typically allow either, but we should set a good example.)
Done

Please name this something else.  Users can easily interpret True to mean "do not do this if the volume is in reserved status", whereas it has precisely the opposite meaning.  Maybe 'force_reserved' or simply 'force'?

More importantly, what is the point of having this flag?  Is the idea that most people will NOT want to re-image a reserved volume, and in between the last time they looked at the volume status and the time this request is being processed, the volume may have transitioned into 'reserved' state, and if so, the user wants the request to fail?  Do users understand the implications of re-imaging a reserved volume sufficiently, or are they just going to always add 'force: True to their requests?
Thanks for renaming the flag.  I think we should say something about this in the api-ref.

Again, I might miss the original intention but my interpretation of this flag is when nova is NOT making this request.
So when nova calls this API, we are adding a new boolean parameter to the API ``reimage_boot_volume`` which users need to explicitly specify and will prevent them from accidentally reimaging a boot volume thinking it's ephemeral. So we can safely assume nova calling this API with the ignore_reserved parameter will be safe.
If an end user calls cinder's re-image API (via client or curl) and executes that on an reserved volume, they should explicitly specify if they want do this reimage or not.
This is just an additional layer of confirmation to the cinder API apart from the use case nova is trying to tackle.

Regarding the naming, i think we've a bad precedence of using force for everything and making it confusing for end users as well as developers. I will change this to ``reimage_reserved``, let me know what do you think about it.
This was made a string by If7460b1c8ab4af417 for v1-compatibility (but why??? it's v2!!!), but we don't want to encourage this kind of thing (compare to line 217).
I'm also not sure why this was done but since this is outside the scope of this change, i can address that in a separate patch if required.

Is there any effect on backups or snapshots of the volume?  I guess it's obvious that if you restore an old backup, you will get the old image?  Since this is really a new volume, are existing snapshots invalid?

This is a data path change so only the contents of the volume will be modified and dependent resources like backup and snapshots should not be affected.
You're correct, if we restore an old backup or snapshot, we will get the old image back but if we think irrespective of the volume being a boot volume or not, the purpose of a snapshot/backup is to return the content of a volume to that point when these resources were created so i think the functionally everything will behave correctly as they should.
Since this is a valid concern, i will add a point regarding this.

Given that volumes are usually of much larger size than an image, it needs to be completely clear that this operation doesn't simply "re-image" the image part of a bootable volume -- it completely destroys all data in the volume and replaces it with the new image.  (Unless there's some way around that?  But from what I can tell, this proposal is wiping out all current volume data and writing the new image.)
Done

I think we should say something in the api-ref, probably in the description of the
'reimage_reserved' field) that reimaging a reserved volume should normally be done only by the Compute service, so we're requiring this flag to indicate that the caller understands that they are requesting reimaging of a reserved volume.

Hi Bob! There is a scaling variable called TIS_WORERS_FACTORS in keystone-all and it is set to 1.5 for all controllers(expect for AIO). So when I specify that I only want a maximum of 10 workers assigned to system controller in my puppet file it will be adjusted to 15 because of this scaling variable. I am trying to avoid such scenario by removing this scaling factor.
sp: TIS_WORKERS_FACTOR
Done

I'm not in the loop on the activities here. Looks like we are removing this factor so that we just use the requested number of workers. No additional scaling based on worker node type is needed? Or is this now handled in a different manner (i.e worker adjustment calculations in puppet)?
Added you to the related change. But there's no additional scaling to the numbers of workers based on the node type.

This factor was introduced after keystone-admin workers were removed from the upstream keystone project many years ago and the author wanted to make sure there were enough keystone workers to support platform operations. 

It is obsolete for StarlingX project as platform services make requests to platform keystone service while Open Stack services make requests to containerized keystone service. Having this factor results in excessive number of keystone workers that are not utilized. Furthermore, any required adjustments to the number of keystone workers should be made to the service puppet file (i.e. keystone.pp) not this file.
Still missing a "T"
Done

we want to do the most recently opened asyncs because on a long cycle (with a long interval) the ones opened most recently from disk have had the least amount of time to become stale from an object-server overwrite

there's nothing in the order that makes the later updates older or newer - they just have a higher chance of being more representative of what's on disk (which is what we'd always processed before)

By mocking the RateLimitIterator rather then the spawn, we can control time before it gets into the bucket ratelimiter. So we get much more control. Each latency is now triggered for each iteration. Joe or Al, do either of you have an explanation for why we need this change, or worded another way, why the spec file as originally taken from Fedora requires this extra call to grub (or why Fedora doesn't need it)?  It just worries me that something else about it may not quite be compatible with our CentOS environment, and we may not trip over that incompatibility until a very inopportune moment months from now.
Reply to comment.

The basic issue is that the grub boot default is only changed when a kernel is removed.  The way the scriplets work is to update the grub options (and default) for the kernel being removed, then update the options (but not the default) for the kernel being added.  This works fine if you are installing a new kernel, booting to it, then removing the old one, but that is not what we do.  I think the "right" way to do things is to change kernel-install, but the "easy" way to fix the problem is to make sure posttrans updates the grub default.

Since the issue is calling "kernel-install remove" which is owned by systemd,  the underlying problem is probably this open bug in systemd (but I am guessing because I know zero about kernel/grub/systemd stuff)  however what seems to happen (ie:  the entry gets set to 'rescue' instead of picking some other kernel, sounds about right.
https://github.com/systemd/systemd/issues/18390

Thanks for the explanation guys.  This is the type of thing that should go into the commit header so that somebody like myself, with the memory of a goldfish, can look at it months later and have a clue as to why we had to do this.  I might suggest using "proper long term solution" instead of "right way" and "expedient" instead of "easy". ;)

specs/yoga/optimize-upload-volume-to-rbd.message: An alternative would be to design the Glance feature so that the store info you need isn't exposed if the operator is worried about the security impact.  I think it needs to be handled on the Glance side, because from the cinder point of view, given the performance data you cite below, the cinder operator will definitely want to have this feature enabled.

I understand the reasoning and need for glance to provide confirmation and take part in this operation but my only concern is there is no good place to put the check throughout the flow of this operation.
There are two calls to glance and I don't find either to be suitable for this check for the following reasons:

1) calling the stores detail API[1]: As mentioned in the glance spec[2], this sounds good for this particular usecase to add the check here but what happens when we extend this API for other stores or use the rbd store properties for any other purpose than this optimization? This makes the new API restricted to this optimization only which is not the intention and doesn't seem right to me.

2) registering the location[3]: During the time this is called, the image clone is already created so if the glance check fails, we have to revert the whole process and i think the check only makes sense at the start of operation to avoid all this cleanup.

Regarding the cinder operator using this config option for performance benefit, we can explain the security impact in the description of this new config option so they just don't go with performance but also understand the security risks of enabling it.
That seems to be the only available option to me, what do you think?

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/809523/4/cinder/volume/drivers/rbd.py#1712
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/glance-specs/+/817391/comment/f24b209a_351da811/
[3] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/809523/4/cinder/volume/drivers/rbd.py#1733
